Award.AwardTitle: Generating Engagement and New Initiatives for All Latinos (GENIAL): Informal Science Education Para Todos

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As a part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds research and innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. This conference will convene Informal Science Education researchers, practitioners, policymakers, and others focusing on generating engagement and new initiatives for Latinos. The goals of the conference are to assess the current state of the field in providing effective ISE experiences for Latinos, identify needs and gaps leading to collaborative research, and synthesize effective strategies that enrich STEM learning for Latinos.

The conference will gather 100 participants face-to-face in September 2016 at the Exploratorium in San Francisco, CA. A follow up workshop for another 40 participants will be held in October 2017 at the Association of Science-Technology Centers annual meeting. Conference outcomes include: identification of areas of future research; new and strengthened partnerships between practitioners and researchers; and a set of principles and guidelines for designing effective informal learning experiences for and with Latinos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The GENIAL (Generating Engagement and New Initiatives for All Latinos/Generando Entusiasmo y Nuevas Iniciativas para Audiencias Latinas) project put forth the following goals: (a) Identify needs and opportunities for Latinos in informal science learning (ISL) environments; (b) Facilitate and strengthen professional relationships; (c) Identify recommendations, emerging research questions, and actionable insights with an outlook toward the future; and, (d) Contribute to a more informed ISL field. To meet these goals, GENIAL successfully organized and implemented a Summit, which was held on June 5–6, 2017 at the Exploratorium in San Francisco, CA. Ninety-one Informal Science Learning (ISL) practitioners, community leaders, media specialists, and researchers from across the United States and Puerto Rico participated. The Summit resulted in a set of actionable insights for sustained engagement of Latinos in ISL, disseminated through Summit proceedings, webinars, and several published articles with selections in English and Spanish. These results contribute to advancing knowledge and understanding within the ISL field, and can inform the work of broadening participation of Latinos in STEM more generally.

The GENIAL Summit was organized around the following strands: 

Strand 1. Latino Audiences

Strand 2. Marketing, Communications, and Media

Strand 3. Community Collaboration and Empowerment

Strand 4. Relevant STEAM Experiences

GENIAL publications include: Summit proceedings, summative evaluation reports, articles written by project advisors focused on the Summit discussion strands, and a GENIAL executive summary and call to action journal article in Informal Learning Review. These publications expand on the meaning and impact of the following actionable insights: 1. Co-create STEAM experiences with, as opposed to for, Latino communities; 2. Spend time and resources understanding Latino communities and identities; 3. Use data for analysis, reflection, and action in conjunction with community dialogue; 4. Cultivate ownership of the work across every function of the ISL organization to break down barriers and prevent assigning diversity work to only a few staff; 5. Acknowledge and shift power dynamics for authentic reciprocity; and 6. Celebrate successes, accept failure as part of the process, and work towards organizational change.

GENIAL results were disseminated through two webinars (produced by ASTC and CAISE) for Summit participants and the broader ISL community. The hour long webinars provided opportunity to process the actionable insights of GENIAL in the context of practitioner's own work. Dissemination of GENIAL results also took place internally at the Exploratorium and through the attendance of the GENIAL organizing team and advisors at national meetings including ASTC and AAM.

Evaluation findings demonstrate that the GENIAL Summit met its stated goals. Like a pebble in the pond, the success of the Summit ripples out into the ISL world as participants actively work towards all the GENIAL ideals at their various institutions throughout the country. Activities which these participants are engaged in are influencing organizational change from varied angles. A majority of the GENIAL-related projects these participants have expanded or initiated since the Summit relate to building human capital, the heart of any organization. They are working to deepen cultural competency and diversity among staff and volunteers. They are also growing relations with Latino communities, and bringing them into the fold for personnel and program development. GENIAL participants expressed a strong affinity for each other, and for all people engaged in efforts to be more inclusive. They also voiced a strong need to be and stay connected with each other, not just to learn from one another, but to provide emotional support and professional development opportunities. Many GENIAL participants feel alone at their institutions; for them this is a difficult fight and it’s easy to get discouraged. Participants expressed the desire to be part of a framework of professional development opportunities and continued in-person gatherings at a regional and/or national level.

The GENIAL Summit offered a renewed and strengthened platform of knowledge and strategies for the participants, who felt supported within a group of colleagues that were dedicated to the same cause. Because the GENIAL Actionable Insights pertain to diverse audiences in general, the Summit results can inform NSF policy makers and federally-sponsored projects focused on increasing STEM engagement of diverse communities more broadly. The Summit, even a full year after its implementation, continues to foster in participants a deeper understanding of how to support cultural identity in STEM through sustained engagement. Such work is critically important to the future and sustainability of the ISL field and to US STEM leadership.

To learn more about the GENIAL Summit publications, proceedings, webinars, and what's coming next please go to the GENIAL webpage
